title: Paper: Midwifery FQE July 2023
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - July 2023

questions.question: In the development of the zygote, one of the following processes correctly characterizes the early stages of cleavage:

options.text: Increased number of cells in the zygote
Formation of a hollow ball of cells
Increase in the size of cells in the zygote

questions.explanation: Cleavage is a series of rapid mitotic cell divisions that increase the number of cells (blastomeres) without increasing the total mass/size of the zygote.
questions.hint: More cells, same total size.

questions.question: In multiple pregnancy, superfetation refers to the conception of twins from:

options.text: Sperms of different men within the same menstrual cycle
Sperms of different men within two different menstrual cycles
Two coital acts in two different menstrual cycles
Two coital acts within the same menstrual cycle

questions.explanation: Superfetation is the formation of a second fetus while another is already present in the uterus (conception during two different cycles). Conception within the same cycle is Superfecundation.
questions.hint: Conception happens when one baby is already there.

questions.question: A nurse assessing the uterine fundus of a mother in the immediate postpartum period notes that the uterus feels soft and boggy. Which would be the most appropriate initial nursing intervention:

options.text: Push on the uterus to assist in expressing clots
Massage the fundus until it is firm

questions.explanation: A boggy uterus indicates uterine atony. Fundal massage stimulates contraction to arrest bleeding. Pushing on a boggy uterus can cause inversion.
questions.hint: Rub it to make it hard.

questions.question: One of the following statements is correct with regard to the sacrum in a gynaecoid pelvis:

options.text: Forms the posterior wall of the pelvic cavity
Forms the anterior wall of the pelvic cavity
The sacrum is one of the components of the innominate bone

questions.explanation: The sacrum forms the posterior wall of the pelvis. It consists of 5 fused vertebrae, not 8. The innominate bone is formed by the ilium, ischium, and pubis.
questions.hint: It's the bone at the back.

questions.question: One of the following is a function of the luteinizing hormone:

options.text: Thickening the endometrium layer for implantation
Breaking down the wall of the graffian follicle to allow the release of the ovum

questions.explanation: The 'LH Surge' triggers ovulation, which is the rupture of the Graafian follicle walls to release the ovum.
questions.hint: It triggers the 'pop' of the egg.

questions.question: During physiological changes of the breast prenatally, montgomery's tubercles become more prominent on the areola between:
questions.explanation: Montgomery's tubercles (sebaceous glands) enlarge early in pregnancy, typically becoming prominent around 8-12 weeks.
questions.hint: This happens in the first trimester.

questions.question: Ms. K delivered a week ago but lactation has totally failed. The correct statement explaining the cause is:

options.text: She started strict dieting immediately after delivery
Her breasts are genetically unable to produce milk
She has suffered severe and prolonged blood loss
This is a normal outcome due to involution of the uterus

questions.explanation: This describes Sheehan's Syndrome (Postpartum Pituitary Necrosis). Severe hemorrhage leads to ischemia of the pituitary gland, preventing Prolactin secretion.
questions.hint: Think about the effect of severe bleeding on the brain's glands.

questions.question: During a routine prenatal visit, a nurse performing a breast exam on Ms. K notices a lump. The most appropriate action is:

options.text: Inform the woman that breast lumps are common and require no further evaluation
Recommend a mammogram to rule out cancer immediately
Refer the woman to a breast specialist for further evaluation
Advise the woman to monitor the lump herself

questions.explanation: Any lump in pregnancy must be evaluated to rule out malignancy. Referral to a specialist is the safest and correct protocol.
questions.hint: Don't ignore lumps in pregnancy.

questions.question: During labour, which statement describes how to assess the frequency of contractions?

options.text: Assessing from the beginning of a contraction to the end of the same contraction
Assessing the number of contractions a patient is experiencing every 30 minutes
Assessing the time the contraction has started to the time it weakens
Assessing the number of contractions the patient has within a duration of 10 minutes

questions.explanation: Frequency is clinically defined and recorded on the partograph as the number of contractions occurring in a 10-minute window.
questions.hint: Count how many in 10 minutes.

questions.question: One of the following statements is correct with regards to maternal physiological changes during the second stage of labour:

options.text: The diaphragm and abdominal muscles become less active
Anteriorly, rectum is compressed along the sacral curve
Laterally, the urinary bladder is pushed upwards into the abdomen
There's an increase in cardiac output by 30-40%

questions.explanation: Cardiac output increases significantly (30-50%) during the second stage due to pain, pushing effort, and autotransfusion from the contracting uterus.
questions.hint: The heart works much harder during pushing.

questions.question: Which immediate intervention is essential for the care of a low birth weight baby?
questions.explanation: Early feeding is critical to prevent hypoglycemia, which LBW babies are prone to due to low glycogen stores.
questions.hint: Prevent low blood sugar.

questions.question: A breastfeeding woman reports nipple pain and discomfort during breastfeeding. Which of the following would be the cause?
questions.explanation: Thrush (Candida) causes sharp, shooting nipple pain that often persists between feeds.
questions.hint: A fungal infection.

questions.question: Changes that take place in the cardio-vascular system during pregnancy include:

options.text: High risk of thrombosis, increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased blood flow to the kidneys, increased heart rate and stroke volume
Decreased plasma protein concentration, decreased iron requirements
Increased heart rate and stroke volume, increased blood flow to the liver

questions.explanation: Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state (risk of thrombosis). Cardiac output increases via increased heart rate and stroke volume.
questions.hint: More blood pumping and 'sticky' blood.

questions.question: What is the primary risk factor for the development of pyelonephritis during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Untreated lower UTI (cystitis) or asymptomatic bacteriuria ascends to the kidneys causing pyelonephritis.
questions.hint: Infection moving up from the bladder.

questions.question: Ms. H is in active labour. The midwife notes descent as 3/5 on abdominal palpation. This means that:

options.text: The fetal head is completely above the pelvic brim
The sinciput is easily felt & occiput just felt
The sinciput is high & occiput easily felt
The sinciput is felt & occiput not felt

questions.explanation: At 3/5 descent, the head is engaging. Approximately 3/5 of the head is palpable above the brim. Usually, the Sinciput is easily felt (3 fingers) and Occiput is lower/just felt (2 fingers descended).
questions.hint: 3 fingers above the brim.

questions.question: One of the following is a role of the midwife during the fourth stage of labour:

options.text: Monitoring of the vital signs every 15 minutes
Monitoring of the vital signs every 45 minutes
Performing daily examination of the newborn

questions.explanation: The 4th stage involves close monitoring of maternal vitals and bleeding every 15 minutes for the first hour to detect PPH.
questions.hint: Very frequent checks right after birth.

questions.question: TRUE or FALSE: The drug of choice for management of Falciparum malaria in first trimester is Artemether-Lumefantrine.
questions.explanation: In the first trimester, Quinine is typically the recommended drug of choice for uncomplicated malaria to avoid potential risks associated with Artemisinins in early pregnancy (though guidelines are evolving, this is the standard exam answer).
questions.hint: Quinine is preferred in the first trimester.

questions.question: One of the following is an indication for trial of scar:

options.text: Estimated fetal weight less than 4500 grams

questions.explanation: Trial of Scar is indicated if the previous reason for CS is non-recurring (e.g., breech, fetal distress) and there are no contraindications.
questions.hint: The reason for the first cut won't happen again.

questions.question: In maternal death surveillance and response, zero reporting principle means:

options.text: No maternal death has occurred within the last 24 hours
A maternal death occurred in the last 24 hours but was not reported
No home deliveries have been reported

questions.explanation: Zero reporting means actively reporting that '0' deaths occurred, rather than just remaining silent.
questions.hint: You must report even if the number is zero.

questions.question: Uterine inversion is considered an obstetric emergency. Which nursing intervention should be prioritized?
questions.explanation: Immediate replacement (Johnson's maneuver) is critical before the cervix contracts and traps the uterus or edema sets in.
questions.hint: Put it back immediately.

questions.question: Delivery of a breech presentation with an extended head is accomplished through:
questions.explanation: Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit maneuver is specifically for delivering the aftercoming head, especially if extended.
questions.hint: A long name for a head maneuver.

questions.question: When monitoring labour for a client with placenta praevia type I, the nurse should monitor closely for:
questions.explanation: Type I (low lying) placenta can bleed as the lower uterine segment stretches and cervix dilates during labor.
questions.hint: Bleeding during labor.

questions.question: A client, 34 weeks pregnant comes with severe abdominal pain, uterine tenderness and increased uterine tone. She denies vaginal bleeding. The client is most likely having:
questions.explanation: These are classic signs of Concealed Abruptio Placentae (pain, woody hard uterus, no visible bleeding).
questions.hint: Concealed bleeding behind the placenta.

questions.question: The analysis of the foetal deaths from 22 weeks gestation up to the first 7 days post-partumly is an accurate measure of the:
questions.explanation: Perinatal mortality includes Stillbirths + Early Neonatal Deaths (0-7 days).
questions.hint: Peri means around (around the time of birth).

questions.question: Mrs. T is receiving heparin for thrombophlebitis. Which drug would the nurse expect to administer if the patient develops complications related to heparin therapy?
questions.explanation: Protamine Sulphate is the specific antidote for Heparin.
questions.hint: The antidote for heparin.

questions.question: Baby J, a female neonate has been diagnosed with Turner’s syndrome. This implies that:

options.text: She has one missing X chromosome
She has an extra X chromosome
There is trisomy of chromosome number 21
She has low-set ears on initial examination

questions.explanation: Turner Syndrome is 45,X (Monosomy X), meaning one X chromosome is missing.
questions.hint: Missing an X.

questions.question: During the initial assessment of a newborn, when measuring the head circumference, the nurse would most appropriately:

options.text: Wrap the tape measure around the infant's head and measure just above the eyebrows
Place the tape measure under the base of the skull and wrap around just above the eyes
Wrap around the occiput and measure just above the eyes
Wrap around the back of the head and across the infant's mouth

questions.explanation: OFC is measured over the occipital protuberance and supraorbital ridges (just above eyebrows).
questions.hint: Around the biggest part of the head, above the brows.

questions.question: The midwife is providing instructions to the mother of a newborn with hyperbilirubinemia. The midwife should instruct the mother to:

options.text: Continue to breastfeed the newborn every 3 hours
Switch to bottle-feeding the baby for 2 weeks
Stop breastfeeding and switch to bottle-feeding permanently
Feed the newborn infant less frequently

questions.explanation: Frequent breastfeeding increases stooling, which helps eliminate bilirubin.
questions.hint: Feed more often to poop out the jaundice.

questions.question: One of the following findings is noted when assessing a newborn born to a mother who is addicted to drugs:
questions.explanation: Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (withdrawal) causes CNS hyperirritability, including high-pitched incessant crying.
questions.hint: The baby is irritable and withdrawing.

questions.question: The rationale of vitamin K administration to newborns after birth is:

options.text: Vitamin K helps the neonate to develop immunity
Vitamin K protects newborns from developing jaundice
Vitamin K protects the newborns from abnormal bleeding
Vitamin K promotes the growth of normal bacteria

questions.explanation: Vitamin K prevents Hemorrhagic Disease of the Newborn by enabling clotting factor synthesis.
questions.hint: K for Koagulation (Clotting).

questions.question: One of the following clinical features when noted on a newborn, would require the midwife to summon the neonatologist:
questions.explanation: Retractions indicate respiratory distress. The others are normal or benign newborn findings.
questions.hint: Signs of breathing difficulty.

questions.question: A 30-year-old patient is diagnosed with gestational diabetes. One of the following tests is used to confirm the diagnosis:
questions.explanation: The 3-hour OGTT (or 2-hour 75g test) is diagnostic. The 1-hour test is for screening.
questions.hint: The longer test confirms it.

questions.question: Which one of the following warning signs when present is indicative of shoulder dystocia?
questions.explanation: Turtle's sign is the retraction of the fetal head against the perineum after it emerges.
questions.hint: The head pops out and pulls back in.

questions.question: Mrs. D is being augmented with oxytocin. Why must the nurse monitor fluid intake and output closely?

options.text: Oxytocin is toxic to the kidneys

questions.explanation: Oxytocin has an antidiuretic effect (similar to ADH) and can cause water retention and hyponatremia.
questions.hint: It acts like ADH.

questions.question: Five hours after birth, a neonate is transferred to the NBU. What is a common source of heat loss via radiation?
questions.explanation: Radiation is heat loss to cooler solid objects not in direct contact, like cold incubator walls or windows.
questions.hint: Heat radiating to a cold surface nearby.

questions.question: A midwife realizes a client has a cord prolapse during vaginal examination. The initial action is to:

options.text: Place the patient in the knee-chest position
Call the delivery room for immediate delivery
Gently replace the cord into the vagina
Call the hospital's obstetrician for an immediate C/S

questions.explanation: Immediate positioning (Knee-chest or Trendelenburg) relieves pressure on the cord. Ideally, the examiner's hand should also remain in the vagina to lift the presenting part.
questions.hint: Gravity helps keep the baby off the cord.

questions.question: On the diagnosis of suspected foetal compromise, which one of the following will be administered as the fluid of choice?

options.text: One litre of 5% dextrose for half an hour
Half a litre of 10% dextrose for one hour
One litre of normal saline for half an hour
A bolus of 50 mls of 50% dextrose

questions.explanation: Rapid fluid loading (bolus) with crystalloids like Normal Saline improves uterine blood flow and oxygenation. Dextrose is avoided to prevent fetal lactic acidosis.
questions.hint: Isotonic fluid.

questions.question: Which type of birth injury involves damage to the brachial plexus nerves?
questions.explanation: Klumpke's palsy and Erb's palsy are injuries to the brachial plexus nerve roots.
questions.hint: It causes arm paralysis.

questions.question: One of the following is a correct management approach of primary postpartum haemorrhage due to uterine atony:

options.text: Administration of carboprost 0.25 mg I.M. every 15 minutes
Taking the client for abdominal surgery with hysterotomy

questions.explanation: Carboprost (Hemabate/Prostaglandin F2a) is a potent uterotonic used when oxytocin fails.
questions.hint: A prostaglandin drug.

questions.question: Match the following organs of the female genitalia in column A with their correct description in column B:

pairs.right: Is the oval-shaped area enclosed by the labia minora
Are circular recesses/deeps within the vagina

questions.explanation: The vestibule is the area between the labia minora. Fornices are the spaces around the cervix in the vagina.
questions.hint: Vestibule is an entrance; Fornices are pockets.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram showing the longitudinal diameters of the fetal skull.
questions.explanation: Key diameters: Sub-occipito-bregmatic (9.5cm), Sub-occipito-frontal (10cm), Occipito-frontal (11.5cm), Mento-vertical (13.5cm), Sub-mento-bregmatic (9.5cm).
questions.hint: Requires drawing the skull profile and indicating measurements.

questions.question: State five (5) hormones produced by the placenta. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The placenta produces hCG, hPL, Estrogen, Progesterone, and Relaxin.
questions.hint: Pregnancy hormones.

questions.question: Outline five (5) roles of the midwife in the prevention of anaemia in pregnancy. (Select 5)

options.text: Routine Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation

questions.explanation: Prevention involves diet, supplements, treating infections (malaria/worms), and monitoring.
questions.hint: Think nutrition and infection control.

questions.question: Explain three (3) specific management decisions for a woman with PPROM at 30 weeks with a stable fetus. (Select 3)
questions.explanation: At 30 weeks (preterm), the goal is to prolong pregnancy if stable. Steroids help lungs, antibiotics prevent infection.
questions.hint: Try to keep the baby inside a bit longer.

questions.question: State four (4) findings suggestive of an obstructed labour on vaginal examination. (Select 4)
questions.explanation: Obstruction signs: Caput, Moulding, Edema, Dryness.
questions.hint: Signs of pressure and lack of progress.

questions.question: State five (5) warning signs of imminent eclampsia. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: These signs indicate cerebral irritation preceding a seizure.
questions.hint: Head, Eyes, Stomach, Reflexes.

questions.question: State five (5) clinical features of a small for gestational age (SGA) at term neonate. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: SGA babies look wasted/starved due to intrauterine malnutrition.
questions.hint: They look like little old men.

questions.question: Explain five (5) clinical features suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in the neonate. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: RDS signs: Grunting, Flaring, Retracting, Tachypnea, Cyanosis.
questions.hint: Struggling to breathe.

questions.question: Regarding 'Vanishing Twin Syndrome' and management of Mrs. T with multiple pregnancy: Select the correct management steps. (Select 4)

options.text: Explain that vanishing twin involves spontaneous resorption of one fetus
Monitor closely for Pre-eclampsia and Anemia

questions.explanation: Management involves explaining the syndrome (resorption), and then managing the remaining multiple/high-risk pregnancy with frequent visits, nutrition, and monitoring for complications.
questions.hint: Manage as a high-risk multiple pregnancy.
